abstract.p: Willam B Pressman letter disputes August 21 letter on loss of potential source of energy through export of New York's garbage to out-of-state landfills

block.p: An Aug. 21 letter discusses the needless loss of a potential source of energy through the export of New York's garbage to out-of-state landfills. But much of this energy would be available if the food-waste portion of the trash -- about 15 percent of the city's solid waste -- were ground by residents with in-sink food-waste disposers, which have recently been made legal in the city.

An Aug. 21 letter discusses the needless loss of a potential source of energy through the export of New York's garbage to out-of-state landfills. But much of this energy would be available if the food-waste portion of the trash -- about 15 percent of the city's solid waste -- were ground by residents with in-sink food-waste disposers, which have recently been made legal in the city.

The infrastructure is already in place in the city's water-pollution control network, which not only conveys ground garbage efficiently and noiselessly to 14 waste-water treatment plants but also converts most of the resulting sludge to methane gas, which is used as fuel to reduce the cost of plant operation.
Why pay for gasification plants and additional transportation when we can already take advantage of our modern water pollution control network?
WILLIAM B. PRESSMAN Jamaica, Queens, Aug. 21, 2000
The writer was director of research and development, New York City Environmental Protection Department.
